title: 106_hr942
content: The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" amends the Communications Act of 1934 by adding a new section that revises duopoly rules. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act amends duopoly rules by allowing ownership of two stations with overlapping coverage contours in separate television markets or two television stations within the same market if one is a UHF station. Existing local marketing agreements between stations in the same market are protected, and ownership of two VHF stations may be permitted in exceptional circumstances. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act allows ownership of two VHF television stations within the same market under exceptional circumstances, if it does not harm competition or media diversity. SEC. 3. CROSS-OWNERSHIP LIMITATIONS. The Federal Communications Commission is required to make rule changes to eliminate restrictions on granting broadcast station licenses based on ownership of a daily newspaper and to remove the one-to-a-market rule. Additionally, minority voting stock interests will not be considered a cognizable interest if one holder owns more than 50% of the voting stock. Cable cross-ownership limitations under the Communications Act of 1934 are also amended. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to allow ownership of both broadcasting stations and cable systems in the same community. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to permit television broadcast stations to affiliate with multiple networks under certain conditions. The Federal Communications Commission must complete necessary modifications within 90 days of the enactment of the Act to allow ownership of broadcasting stations and cable systems in the same community. SEC. 4 amends the Telecommunications Act of 1996 to increase the ownership limit from 35% to 45%. The Federal Communications Commission must implement this change within 90 days. SEC. 5 addresses reciprocal treatment of foreign ownership restrictions. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses, aeronautical radio stations, and corporations with significant foreign ownership. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses, aeronautical radio stations, and corporations with significant foreign ownership. One-fourth of any class of the capital stock is owned by aliens, their representatives, or a foreign government, if the public interest will be served by the refusal or revocation of such license. Reciprocal treatment for broadcast stations is required if the foreign country regularly permits licenses to be held by corporations with significant US ownership. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses, aeronautical radio stations, and corporations with significant foreign ownership. If one-fourth of the capital stock is owned or voted by one or more United States persons, the Commission may allow a foreign entity to own a portion of the capital stock of a corporation seeking a broadcast station license, up to 40% of the voting stock. The term 'United States person' includes corporations organized under state laws. The term 'United States person' in the Communications Act of 1934 refers to corporations organized under state laws, individuals who are U.S. citizens, U.S. government entities, or representatives of these entities.
